verses.text: Six days later, Jesus took Peter, James, and John his brother, and led them up a high mountain by themselves.
verses.comment: The narrative places this event shortly after Peter's confession, emphasizing Jesus' intentional choice of these three core disciples for a special revelation.

verses.text: He was transfigured before them, and his face shone like the sun, and his clothes became as white as light.
verses.comment: The transfiguration reveals Jesus' divine nature and glory, connecting him to Old Testament theophanies and foreshadowing his resurrected state.

verses.text: Suddenly, Moses and Elijah appeared to them, talking with him.
verses.comment: Moses and Elijah represent the Law and the Prophets, showing Jesus as fulfillment of both. Their presence also affirms belief in life after death and the communion of saints.

verses.text: Peter said to Jesus, 'Lord, it is good for us to be here. If you wish, I will put up three shelters—one for you, one for Moses, and one for Elijah.'
verses.comment: Peter's offer echoes the Feast of Tabernacles and shows his desire to remain in God's presence. The three shelters suggest an instinct for honoring holy figures distinctly.

verses.text: While he was still speaking, a bright cloud covered them, and a voice from the cloud said, 'This is my beloved Son, with whom I am well pleased; listen to him.'
verses.comment: The Father's voice affirms Jesus' sonship and authority, paralleling the baptism and signaling the fulfillment of prophecy regarding a divine prophet one must obey.

verses.text: When the disciples heard this, they fell facedown to the ground, terrified.
verses.comment: Encountering God's glory causes fear and awe—a common reaction throughout scripture when mortals witness divine manifestations.

verses.text: But Jesus came and touched them, saying, 'Rise, and do not be afraid.'
verses.comment: Jesus reassures his disciples, demonstrating compassionate authority and intimacy, like a mediator between God and humanity.

verses.text: When they lifted their eyes, they saw no one except Jesus alone.
verses.comment: Moses and Elijah vanish, leaving Jesus as the unique focal point, stressing the transition from the old covenant to Christ's definitive revelation.

verses.text: As they were coming down the mountain, Jesus commanded them, 'Do not tell anyone the vision until the Son of Man has been raised from the dead.'
verses.comment: Jesus reveals his resurrection, indicating his divine triumph over death and instructing silent witness until his glory is fully unveiled.

verses.text: The disciples asked him, 'Why then do the scribes say that Elijah must come first?'
verses.comment: This question reflects Jewish expectation of Elijah's return as a precursor to the Messiah, based on prophecy.

verses.text: He replied, 'Elijah certainly comes and will restore all things.'
verses.comment: Jesus affirms the prophetic role of Elijah, signaling restoration and preparation for the Messiah.

verses.text: But I tell you, Elijah has already come, and they did not recognize him, but did to him everything they wished. In the same way, the Son of Man will also suffer at their hands.
verses.comment: Jesus interprets John the Baptist as fulfilling Elijah's ministry, paralleling his own future suffering—fulfilling the prophetic pattern of rejection and sacrifice.

verses.text: Then the disciples understood that he was talking to them about John the Baptist.
verses.comment: The disciples recognize the symbolic fulfillment in John the Baptist, clarifying the continuity of prophecy and divine intervention.

verses.text: When they reached the crowd, a man came up to him, knelt before him,
verses.comment: The posture of kneeling shows humility and reverence—a recognition of Jesus' authority.

verses.text: and said, 'Lord, have mercy on my son, for he has seizures and suffers greatly. Often he falls into the fire and often into the water.'
verses.comment: The man's request for mercy and his son's suffering draw attention to Jesus' role in healing and compassion—a foreshadowing of sacramental mercy.

verses.text: 'I brought him to your disciples, but they were not able to heal him.'
verses.comment: The disciples’ inability highlights the need for deeper faith and dependence on Jesus, not mere technique.

verses.text: Jesus answered, 'O faithless and twisted generation! How long must I be with you? How long must I put up with you? Bring him here to me.'
verses.comment: Jesus’ rebuke underscores faith as central to healing and relationship with God—miracles flow from a living faith.

verses.text: Jesus rebuked the demon, and it came out of him, and from that moment the boy was healed.
verses.comment: Jesus’ authority over evil spirits is evident here—healing at his command confirms his divine power and the reality of spiritual warfare.

verses.text: Then the disciples came to Jesus privately and asked, 'Why could we not cast it out?'
verses.comment: The disciples' private question indicates an active desire for spiritual growth and understanding deeper mysteries of power.

verses.text: He said to them, 'Because of your little faith. For truly, I say to you, if you have faith as small as a mustard seed, you will say to this mountain, ‘Move from here to there,’ and it will move. Nothing will be impossible for you.'
verses.comment: Even a tiny amount of true faith, joined with God's will, can accomplish the impossible—this image points both to literal wonders and spiritual transformation.

verses.text: [Some manuscripts add: But this kind does not go out except by prayer and fasting.]
verses.comment: The bracketed verse, omitted in some manuscripts, emphasizes the necessity of both prayer and fasting in spiritual battles, developing a robust spiritual discipline.

verses.text: While they were gathering in Galilee, Jesus said to them, 'The Son of Man is about to be delivered into the hands of men,'
verses.comment: Jesus predicts his Passion, showing deliberate acceptance of suffering and sacrifice for the salvation of mankind.

verses.text: 'and they will kill him, and on the third day he will be raised.' And they were greatly distressed.
verses.comment: Jesus openly predicts his death and resurrection—a claim of divine authority, aligning with prophetic expectation of triumph over death.

verses.text: When they came to Capernaum, those who collected the temple tax came to Peter and asked, 'Does your teacher not pay the two-drachma tax?'
verses.comment: The temple tax was a religious obligation for Jews, showing the importance of both civic and religious duties.

verses.text: He said, 'Yes.' When he came into the house, Jesus spoke to him first, saying, 'What do you think, Simon? From whom do the kings of the earth collect taxes or tribute—from their own sons, or from others?'
verses.comment: Jesus’ question points to his unique sonship as God’s Son and suggests his exemption from the temple tax as a sign of his divine position.

verses.text: Peter replied, 'From others.' Jesus said to him, 'Then the children are exempt.'
verses.comment: Jesus implies his divine sonship, affirming the distinction between himself and others—a subtle claim to divinity.

verses.text: But so that we do not cause offense, go to the sea, cast a hook, and take the first fish you catch. Open its mouth, and you will find a coin. Take it and give it to them for me and for you.
verses.comment: Jesus demonstrates supernatural power by providing the coin in an extraordinary way and models humility by fulfilling obligation. This humility and respect for tradition foreshadows the ongoing role of the visible Church in the world—engaging temporal affairs while possessing heavenly authority.
